author: realities.#0

content:
Hey all

Quick meta question: how do you pick what to build? Do you build for fun or as a side hustle? If the latter do you check competitors to "take inspiration" or go freestyle? 

I start to have this sense that 2026 will be the year building anything will truly become democratised. It must then follow that knowing what to build will become a central question - to avoid spending your credits on something that has been tried 23 times.

content: Is it intended that cc uses about 63k context right after a new session is started?
author: demalt#0

content: you can see whats using it with /context auto compaction saves 45k then there is system tools around 20k so sounds about right.
author: stachefkapatass#0

content: this is mine
author: stachefkapatass#0

content: Worth noting that the reservation for autocompact isn't 'used' in the same way, as that's not tokens sent to the model
author: jarlyk#0

content: thank you - i see.
author: demalt#0

content: but using about 20k right from the start just feels wrong
author: demalt#0

content: There are a lot of instructions about how to use the tools
author: jarlyk#0

content: presumably Anthropic has done a fair bit of tuning on finding a good balance of tokens for getting good usage from the tools
author: jarlyk#0

content: they don't have any incentives to be wasteful with tokens, since they're capacity-constrained
author: jarlyk#0

content: but isn't it true that higher token consumption is an incentive to sign up for a higher plan or the fancy /extend-usage command? I assume that this topic has already been discussed a thousand times here üòÑ
author: demalt#0

content: is there a way to only use MCPs when needed instead of loading everything in context right away?
author: antoine1999#0

content: from a consumption perspective, the tools are almost always going to be cached anyway, since system prompt + built-in tools is probably the most reused chunk of context in the entire app
author: jarlyk#0

content: so the token cost for the tools portion of the prompt is tiny compared to the standard rate
author: jarlyk#0

content: Yeah, this is "moral hazard", or "perverse incentive".
author: delphianq#0

content: In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if they have an explicit checkpoint for caching after system prompt + tools (not sure if their API still has that, but at one point you set explicit checkpoints for caching)
author: jarlyk#0

content: cached input tokens on Opus are $0.50/MTok
author: jarlyk#0

content: in case they measure plan usage including cache benefits
author: demalt#0

content: they definitely do consider caching in the usage calculations
author: jarlyk#0

content: at least based on anecdotal observations
author: jarlyk#0

content: the actual usage calculations are a bit loosely defined, but that again goes back to them being capacity-constrained and basically needing to ration available compute
author: jarlyk#0

content: that's why they don't promise like X amount of API usage
author: jarlyk#0

content: it's a better deal than direct API usage, but the cost is that the available usage is not a fixed known quantity that you can pull from as a total pool
author: jarlyk#0

content: If you use the API directly, you can always* get usage, but you pay a premium for that
author: jarlyk#0

content: I work a lot with the api using Open WebUI and Cline - so I know about the painful api costs using Opus. So indeed I think the plans are a good deal - even if it's not really transparent and feels a bit unfair sometimes
author: demalt#0

content: Rationing is always a hard problem, especially when there are actors trying to exploit the system for everything they can get

anyone ever get invited  to top 5 nyc business school to give chat on digital addiction economics dec 2023 ? 

    and after submitting presentation as courtesy   receive feedback requesting presentation rework to 
    narrowly focus only on the disclaimer slide before the table of contents ?

and disclaimer slide was     ~   (and ill go find the file - its in account with 2 factor where id need to dig up a defunct legalentity simcard)
               ~ slide was     the info advantage i have as speaker   even giving a chat like this for first time , 
                                         means you can be the most discerning critique and anticipating 1st , 2nd, 3rd order arguements to planned presentation 
                                         i can word engineer a presentation which    unfairly implants a perspective in the audience (prenisiously) 

                but it was with a demo not an explanation  ... 
                                       i said to audience , i can predict what ever one of you is thinking right now and its not "no he cant"   

and that warning slide never did become a presentation but for good reasons !

content:
I‚Äôve been experimenting with Claude Skills to build reusable AI ‚Äúemployees‚Äù instead of one-off prompts.
The key idea:
Treat AI like infrastructure, not chat.

In this video I cover:
‚Äì Skills vs Projects
‚Äì How to design consistent AI behavior
‚Äì How this fits long-running workflows and automation

Not selling anything ‚Äî just sharing what‚Äôs worked for me.

üé• Video here: https://youtu.be/qFQV1K5ew0Y?si=YcJIBTMKf5oUgaSV

Would love to hear how others here are handling AI consistency.
author: outrageous_puppy_84585#0

content:
You can add this to your `settings.json` to turn it off:

```json
{
  "includeCoAuthoredBy": false,
  "gitAttribution": false
}
```

content:
Happy new year!!!
I‚Äôm a **professional AI, Web3, and full-stack developer** helping startups and founders build **reliable, production-ready systems**.

My work spans across AI engineering, automation platforms, blockchain ecosystems, and web/mobile development, with a strong focus on reliability, performance, and clean architecture.

Some of my core expertise includes:
*  **AI & Automation**: Voice AI agents (Vapi, Retell, Twilio, LiveKit), RAG-based chatbots, TTS/STT, LLM integrations, n8n/Zapier/Make workflows
*  **Web3**: Smart contracts, DApps, NFT marketplaces (Solidity, Ethers.js, Web3.js, Moralis, Thirdweb)
*  **Backend & ML**: Python APIs & pipelines (FastAPI, Flask, TensorFlow, PyTorch)
*  **Frontend & Mobile**: Next.js, React, React Native, Flutter

I prioritize **long-term collaboration, transparency, and real outcomes**, not quick hacks.
If you‚Äôre looking for someone who can own features end-to-end, feel free to DM me here
